LARVAL BEHAVIOR PROBABLY ASSOCIATED WITH RESPIRATION IN
LUCIOLA

SUBSTRIATA
GORHAM ( COLEOPTERA : LAMPYRIDAE )

XIALIN ZHENG, XINHUA FU, SHICHANG ZHANG AND CHAOLIANG LEI1 Key Laboratory of Insect Resource Utilization & Sustainable Pest Management of Hubei Province Huazhong Agricultural University Wuhan 430070, CHINA

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: The larval behaviors probably associated with respiration are reported in different larval

instars of
Luciola substriata Gorham
( Coleoptera : Lampyridae ). The behavior involved
exposing eighth abdominal segment with spiracles to the atmosphere when swim behavior
occurred to 1 st –2 nd and 3 rd –6 th instar larvae. In addition, 3 rd –6 th instar larvae exposed
second to seventh abdominal segments with spiracles to air when swimming. Swimming and
the behavior that uses the force of body curving travelling in a head-to-tail direction
produces a sinusoidal wave. However, probably 1 st –2 nd instar larvae used both tracheal gills
and the exposed posterior spiracle for respiration. Whereas 3 rd –6 th instar larvae lack
tracheal gills, they probably rely only on tracheal respiration. The survival times of 1 st –2 nd
instar larvae were nine times to 3 rd –6 th instar larvae when the water in the beakers was
isolated from atmosphere by a thin plastic membrane. The potential for different selective
pressures acting on these early and late instars was discussed.

Aquatic fireflies attract attention because of their particular external morphology and adaptive behavior in aquatic environments (Jeng et al. 2003; Suzuki et al. 2002, 2004;
a , b ). Majority of previous studies has been focused on the morphology, biology, ethology, ecology and artificial rearing (Okada 1928; Ohba 1988, 1996, 1997; Chen and Chen 1997;
; Fu et al. 2004, 2005 a, b, c , 2006 a, b, c , 2007; Abe et al. 2006; Yuan et al. 2007; Zheng et al. 2007), covering seven species,
Luciola cruciata Motschulsky, Luciola
lateralis Motschulsky, Luciola
ficta Olivier, Luciola
hydrophila Jeng, Luciola owadai Sato et Kimura, Luciola
leii Fu and Ballantyne
, and
Luciola substriata Gorham.

Luciola substriata Gorham
( Coleoptera : Lympyridae: Luciolinae) was a rare aquatic firefly species with two different types of larval stages. The 1 st –2 nd and 3 rd –6 th instar larvae were different from both morphology and behavior (Fu et al. 2004). The former was characterized by the possession of tracheal gills located on the first to seventh abdominal segments and posterior spiracles located on the eighth abdominal segment. The latter was characterized by the possession of spiracles located on the thorax and abdomen, and lacking tracheal gills (Zheng et al. 2007). The 1 st –2 nd instar larvae had tracheae without air sacs, 3 rd –6 th instar larvae had both tracheae and air sacs in the respiratory system (Zheng et al. 2007). The 1 st –2 nd instar larvae crawled mainly in the substrate and were capable of swimming ventral surface up from time to time, 3 rd –6 th instar larvae swam ventral surface up (back swimming) and they also remained stationary at the surface. During their back swimming, we found that 1 st –2 nd and 3 rd –6 th instar larvae could expose their segments with spiracles to the air. We presumed that this kind of

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p:
Insects.
The 1 st –2 nd and 3 rd –6 th instar larvae of
L. substriata
were collected from Lake Tangxun (
30.5 ° N
,
110.3 ° E
), close to Huazhong Agricultural University (HZAU), Wuhan City , Hubei Province , P. R. China in the evening during July to September in 2006. The collected larvae were reared in an aquarium ( 50 cm X 40 cm X 40 cm ), which was filled with lake water and some plants of
Lemna minor
L. (Arecidae: Lemnaceae ) on the surface
.

Experiments. The movements of 1 st –2 nd and 3 rd –6 th instar larvae ( 30 larvae for each type ) were videotaped (SONY DIGITAL ZOOM DCR-TRV530E PAL) in the laboratory. Larvae were fed in a transparent aquarium ( 30 cm X 20 cm X 20 cm ) with 10 cm deep water, and they were filmed from lateral view out of the aquarium. Water temperature was 23 ± 1 ° C and atmosphere temperature was 25 ± 1 ° C. The aquarium had graduations on the lateral to determine the height of the prothorax, second and eighth abdominal segments that exposed to the air of 3 rd –6 th instar larvae. The prothorax, second and eighth abdominal segments of 3 rd –6 th instar larvae were marked red by butyraceous marker pen respectively. The video-tape was evaluated in film player (Real time) by manual advancement per 37 ms to check the position of red segments and determine their exposed height to the air and calculate the exposed time by showing time on video during the swimming sequences. At the same time, we checked and recorded the exposed height and time of second abdominal segment in four cycles. Time of a swimming cycle, exposed time of second to seventh abdominal segments (it is the sum time of second to seventh abdominal segments exposed time to the air by manual advancement to calculate) and eighth segment to the air depend on showing time on video. Additional pictures and a series of swimming behaviors including exposed their abdominal segments with spiracles were took by a camera (OTTIMO SHOTONE 698) according to the video screen. 1 st –2 nd instar larvae of
L. substriata
were put 30 individuals into two beakers (125 mL) respectively, which were full of water. One mouth of the beaker was covered with thin plastic membrane, while another was maintained without the thin plastic membrane. These treatments were repeated using 30 3 rd –6 th instar larvae.

Data Analysis. Data statistics were analyzed using SAS system (SAS Institute 1999–2000). Experimental values were quoted as mean ± standard error. Paired values were compared for significant differences using the t -test at P 5 0.01.
Results 1st–2nd instar larvae exposed their eighth abdominal segment with posterior

spiracles to the air. 1 st –2 nd instar larvae of
L. substriata
displayed two behaviors that exposed their body to the air. Those behaviors involving exposed their eighth abdominal segment to the air in the process of swimming and at rest. Moreover, they may spread their tracheal gills adequately under water.

1 st –2 nd instar larvae had only posterior spiracles located on the eighth abdominal segment. Two conditions were checked: 1) exposed its eighth abdominal segment to the air during back swimming, and 2) exposed its eighth abdominal segment to the air when at rest.

In addition, 1 st –2 nd instar larvae spread their tracheal gills adequately under water. The tracheal gills located on the thorax and first to seventh abdominal segments were extremely spread during crawling, back swimming and rest ( Fig. 1c ).

In the process of back swimming, the motion of prothorax, second and eighth abdominal segment were each different ( Fig. 3 ). In Figure 3 , the second and eighth abdominal segments were each exposed in atmosphere periodically, but the eighth abdominal segments were exposed for the greatest period of time. However, their segments that exposed height on the surface were also different. The eighth abdominal segment was higher than second abdominal segment apparently. In the four cycles of second abdominal segment during back swimming, we found they could expose it on surface in every cycle ( Fig. 4 ).

Generally, the eighth abdominal segment of 3 rd –6 th instar larvae can be exposed to air when resting ( Fig. 5a ). In addition, 3 rd –6 th instar larvae could crawl to the top of leaves to expose their whole body to air ( Fig. 5b ).

Comparing 1 st –2 nd and 3 rd –6 th instar larvae.
1 st –2 nd and 3 rd –6 th instar larvae exposed their eighth abdominal segments with spiracles during back swimming. But, the time for each swimming cycle was different ( P , 0.01) and the exposed time of eighth abdominal segment were also different ( Table 1 ).

The results showed that survival times of 1 st –2 nd and 3 rd –6 th instar larvae were both shorter when the top of the beaker was sealed than when it was left open (no larvae died in two CK). Comparing 1 st –2 nd and 3 rd –6 th instar larvae, the survival times of 1 st –2 nd instar larvae were longer than that of 3 rd –6 th instar larvae when the top of the beaker was sealed ( P , 0.01) ( Fig. 6 ).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The survival times of 1 st –2 nd instar larvae were longer than that of 3 rd –6 th instars ( Fig. 6 ), maybe the reason was that the body of the 1 st –2 nd instar larvae was smaller compared with that of the 3 rd –6 th instars, and they can obtain dissolved oxygen through tracheal gills. On the other hand, 3 rd –6 th instar larvae, without tracheal gills, exposed their abdominal segments to air to breathe by spiracles probably, because 3 rd –6 th instar larvae could not absorb dissolved oxygen under water. At the same time, it may explain why survival times decreased sharply when 3 rd –6 th instar larvae could not expose their abdominal segments to the atmosphere ( Fig. 6 ).

This behavior of exposing their abdominal segments to the atmosphere of
L. substriata
larvae differed from other aquatic firefly larvae owing to their different habits.
Luciola leii
( Coleoptera : Lampyridae ) mainly crawls on the substrate of ditches, streams, or shallow rivers (
), and cannot swim. 1 st –6 th instar larvae of
L. leii
have both spiracles and tracheal gills on their integument.
L. leii
larvae may expose their spiracle to the atmosphere for 5.00 ± 1.30 min (X ± SD, n 5 30 ) when they crawl to the waterside (Zheng et al. 2008). This was similar to the behavior observed in the aquatic firefly larvae of
L. cruciata
,
L. lateralis
and
L. ficta
(unpublished data), but differed from
L. substriata
larvae.

1 st –2 nd and 3 rd –6 th instar larvae of
L. substriata
widely distributed in large water lakes and ponds (
a ). 1 st –2 nd instar larvae floated occasionally at the surface and hid under the aquatic plant leaves to expose their eighth abdominal segment to the atmosphere. Perhaps 1 st –2 nd instar larvae must crawl at the surface by leaves and expose their eighth abdominal segment to the air to breathe by posterior spiracles when they cannot adapt to the hydraulic pressure and decreased dissolved oxygen. In addition, we found many large predatory insects ( e.g .,
Cybister tripunctatus
( Coleoptera : Dytiscidae ) etc.) in the habitat of
L. substriata
. 1 st –2 nd instar larvae probably avoid being preyed upon via this behavior. We presumed that this kind of behavior might be an adaptation to the deep aquatic environment. 3 rd –6 th instar larvae, without tracheal gills, chronically

Lymnaea stagnalis
L. (Basommatophora: Lymnaeidae ) and
Gyraulus convexiusculus Hutton
(Basommatophora: Planorbidae ) live under the leaves of
Lemna minor
L. (Arecidae: Lemnaceae ) and
Alternanthera philoxeroides (Mart.) Griseb
( Caryophyllidae : Amaranthacae) near the surface of the water. Therefore, 3 rd –6 th instar larvae must remain near the surface in order to supply energy and oxygen which were needed to survive. This firefly may have evolved to lose tracheal gills and develop abdominal spiracles without hydrofuge hairs to facilitate simultaneously swim and respiratory behavior in 3 rd –6 th instar larvae. Because the phenomenon that swimming and respiratory behaviors occurred simultaneously not only potentially saves energy while maximizing respiration, but also decreases the chance to be preyed by nature enemies (Adis and Messner 1997).

Aquatic insects show three types of behavior patterns for the purpose of respiration: 1) floating at the surface; 2) making short dives and returning quickly to the surface; 3) swimming actively and constantly during diving episodes which

In the first two cases, the insects can directly expose their spiracles to the atmosphere for respiration, while in the third case the insects must absorb dissolved oxygen in the water (José and José 1994). In this study, we only observed the phenomenon that the larval abdominal segments with spiracles were exposed to the air. However, this case was similar to the first and second categories mentioned above. We assumed that this kind of behavior was associated with respiration of larvae in this aquatic firefly, but it needs further study to verify.
